body: Hi @MillerSvt, thanks for the issue, if i am not wrong `using` keyword is more inclined with typescript right now, so you should open this issue to [typescript-eslint](https://github.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint).

issue.title: Base no-lone-blocks rule: emits an error with `using` keyword

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

labels.name: enhancement: new base rule extension
labels.description: New base rule extension required to handle a TS specific case

labels.name: locked due to age
labels.description: Please open a new issue if you'd like to say more. See https://typescript-eslint.io/contributing.

repository.name: typescript-eslint
repository.description: :sparkles: Monorepo for all the tooling which enables ESLint to support TypeScript

body: This should be in ESLint core. `using` is a JS thing, not a TS thing. It's the same as `class`, `async`, or any other syntaxâ€”the fact that TS provides transpiling support doesn't mean it's TS-only.

This is a new syntax from the [Explicit Resource Management](https://github.com/tc39/proposal-explicit-resource-management) proposal, which is currently in stage 3 status. Per our [policies about experimental features](https://github.com/eslint/eslint?tab=readme-ov-file#what-about-experimental-features), we'll update core rules to support this syntax when the proposal reaches stage 4. Until then, a solution can be that plugins related to parsers that already support this syntax provide replacement rules.

@mdjermanovic In https://github.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/issues/8682, we discovered that ESLint can be future proof simply by switching the check to `if (node.kind !== "var")`. Is there desire to make this change?

> switching the check to `if (node.kind !== "var")`

I think that would be fine. @eslint/eslint-team thoughts?
